commentBody: ALFA is also a correct answer on its face - it's the proper spelling of the first word of the NATO alphabet.

The quip is funny, but in reality, it is untrue.  If you say that words with PH aren't pronounced the way they're spelled, you might as well say that words with CH, SH, and TH (with their normal pronunciations) aren't pronounced the way they're spelled.

PH is just one of two very common ways to spell the /f/ sound, just like C and K are two ways to spell the /k/ sound, or G and J the /dʒ/ sound.

It's also interesting that the Philippines are named after Philip II of Spain, but the people are referred to as Filipinos, from Las Islas Filipinas. Language really is a catchall sometimes.

Love this puzzle, it had everything you'd want in a Thursday puzzle, a good revealer, lots of theme answers and quite a bit of humor. The ambisexual nymphomaniac, for example, always good for a chuckle--until they overstay their welcome on your futon, and leave your tendons frayed. Also liked the "low pair" of ELF and DWARF, the Achilles tendons recalling the Iliad, the bookends of ALPHA and ENDERS, frayed and afraid so, and the odd duo of AMIS and AMOS. 

Good to see Orson Scott Card sharing space with ambisexual: he's been an outspoken homophobe, and even sat on the board of the National Organization for Marriage for 4 years, a group that actively campaigns against gay marriage. I'm told his books occasionally feature self-hating gay characters. But as the puzzle says (good advice in general): LET IT GO. 

Possible good new year's resolution, too. I bet my family is going to say "Let it go!" pretty regularly this coming year...

And here we are with the first rebus (or not-a-rebus) Thursday of the New Shortz Era.  It was neither terrible nor great for me.  As has become too common, I spent more time figuring out what exact format was expected for the trick squares than in actually solving the puzzle.  This always stinks but may be unavoidable for gimmick and rebus puzzles; I don't know.

And, just as has become common, my issue turned out to be not the trick formatting but a flyspecky sort of error - I had Flax and Filipina instead of Phlox and Filipino.  I suspect I'm not alone here, and for a change the count "eight squares in this puzzle" actually helped to uncover the missing Ph square or two and solve the thing.

So, for me, maybe 60% frustrating and 40% fun.  Okay, but not my favorite.  I also thought that "Foto" was a poor choice here, since "foto" is already acceptable slang for a photograph exactly as "snap" is, and so wasn't really a valid substitution / rebus as part of the theme.

This was a pretty cool puzzle, themed around one of the curious aspects of the English language. I did not know the quip but it was easy enough to get with some crosses.

In Polish only the letter F produces an F sound. In general in Polish there is almost always only one way to write down a word for it to be pronounced a certain way. Very few of our words produce sounds that could be written down differently, the chief example being jabłko (apple), which sounds as if it were spelled japko [yapp-ko]. We also have some homophones (but much, much fewer than in English), eg. buk (beech tree), bóg (god) and Buk (the river Bug) all sound the same (it is a sound like your word book).

A great moment in solving crosswords for me is when I’m puzzled over a clue, then suddenly the answer hits me – and that answer makes perfect sense.  I love getting gotten good like that. 

Today, I was gotten good again, but in a different way – by being hit by the unexpected.  After seeing [Start of a quip by comic Steven Wright], I assumed this was simply a quip puzzle.  

Every quip puzzle I’ve seen has a quote to crack and nothing theme-wise beyond that.  So today, when it became clear that there was something else going on – and it was related to the quip – that was a wow.  Here was something new in crosswords!  I just had to stop for a moment, dwell on how clever it was for Robert to come up with that, and nod with respect.

Oh, the solve gave me some lovely resistance, and had lovely touches.  One that especially tickled me was [Achilles, for two], because whenever there's an [x, for two] clue, that “x” is always two items, not one, such as in [“Iliad” and “Odyssey”, for two] for EPICS.  Always.  That’s another crossword first in this puzzle.

Happy surprises and plenty of riddle cracking for me today, Robert. Thank you for a sweet start to the second day of the year!

I want to comment on something I've noticed in the past few days, which is an improvement to the way Wordplay behaves, at least on a PC desktop, running Chrome.

Whereas for a long time, when you opened the comment section, you could not scroll the column (such as when someone made a comment about one of the explanations).  This happened at the same time that the background of the column was changed to gray when the comments were opened, and I'd say this happened maybe a couple of years ago.

Now, in the last few days I've noticed that (at least in my setup), you can scroll the article while reading the comments.  This is how it was before the last change, and is vastly superior to opening and closing the comments every time I needed to refer back, or keeping two separate windows open.

I checked, and this change was not made for other types of articles.  Maybe Wordplay wasn't the only column for which this works, but it's certainly not the case NYT-wide.

I can also remember a time when if you clicked on the puzzle at 10:00 sharp, you took your chances that the new one was up.  Now that's quite reliable, and has been for at least a year or two.

The tech people really can do things if they try.  Hats off in this case!

The clue for 1A allows both ALPHA and ALFA, since each is the first in its respective (Greek, Nato) alphabet. Not sure how I feel about this. The better answer for 1A is certainly ALPHA, since we want each of the eight special squares to be filled with PH/F, i.e., PH is part of the horizontal and F is part of the vertical. That said, I simply put F in each of the eight boxes, and my solution was deemed correct in the online version of the puzzle. Still, I think I'd have preferred a clue like "Pack leader" for 1A.

This is dumb in relation to what a crossword puzzle is for most people. It’s very clever in terms of something other than a basic crossword puzzle. I realize that there is no normative definition of the term. But if you want to make a crossword puzzle an insistent exercise of linguistic tricks, often combined with fairly esoteric insider slang and a lot of obscure, extremely marginal urban references, then you’ve reduced your audience to a smug coterie. Maybe there should be two crossword puzzles a day: one for people with a reasonably sophisticated understanding of linguistic ambiguity plus an ample knowledge of scientific, geographical, and historical lore; and another for people whose minds are trained on esoteric trivia and overly subtle sleights of tongue. 

Are you looking to make your audience smaller? That appears to be your intent.

One of my favorite scenes from a movie is between Spencer Tracy and Emil Jannings in Judgment at Nuremburg:

Emil Jannings plays a judge who convicted a Jewish defendant when he knew there was no evidence to support such a verdict. He says that if he had known what it would come to (the Holocaust), he would not have convicted the man. Spencer Tracy (playing the prosecutor) responds, “When you convicted one person you knew to be innocent, it had already come to that.”

So profound it makes me cry.

If Wright's quip had a false premise embedded in its question, Steve's post would have been on point, but since it merely asks a question about spelling it's not wrong and highlights the irony that of all the words out there one would think "phonetically" would be the most likely to be spelled phonetically.

@B, despite my paranoia, I’ve found for almost all bidirectional, Schroedinger, or rebus puzzles, the format is pretty permissive and flexible (I went with “PH/F” today).

The few exceptions (like the dashed one this week that didn’t take “-/L” as an answer or sleeping cars from last year) annoyingly justify the paranoia when I’m fiddling for many minutes with a bidirectional rebus that maybe it’s the interface/format that is hampering my solve and not my actual incompetence (it usually is my actual incompetence).

The exceptions of late happen to be easier solves with fairly straightforward fills, but their existence makes bidirectional puzzles that follow conventional formatting with tougher fills that induce fiddling (like the one today) even tougher with doubts about formatting.

It would be fantastic if the editors could make a commitment to consistent formatting so solvers don’t have to guess.

@Steve 

Yep I think permissiveness is key.  Just accept every possible square filling the editorial team can imagine.  And if there are more than 2 or 3 (tops) reasonable fills, then maybe the puzzle isn't really designed well enough yet, so put it back in to bake a bit longer...

@ds so the comments section is only for positive comments?

@ba

I for one fully enjoy comments such as yours which describe what it is the poster didn't care for in a puzzle -- and have done so myself from time to time. I often learn things from the "nits" that people post!

But the all-too-frequent use of the snarky "do better" is a total turnoff. And calling a construction "lazy" and "unfair" -- also dare I say way too loosely and frequently tossed around -- is beyond inappropriate. A *lot* of work goes into any given NYT crossword, by a team of people, and a very high bar is set for publication. 

Clues were "vague, misleading or borderline nonsensical"? Though we don't know which the OP is referencing, I'd venture to say to the contrary, that's top- level wordplay. Nothing lazy about it!
@Angr which clues were nonsensical?

@G I agree "do better" is not constructive! I confess I do not know much about how the sausage is made, but it has me wondering if there is some law of diminishing returns with a cool theme versus some questionable 3/4 letter words...phood for thought (sorry)

@Ray 

No, but comments that show very little understanding have a right to be rebutted.  

For one thing, the commenter may not realize that when Thursday (or any day) puzzles are "vague or misleading", that's a feature, not a flaw, and it's on the solver to figure them out.  

When a solver says clues are "nonsensical," it usually means they didn't understand them.  I didn't find anything nonsensical, so if the OP had simply asked for an explanation on any clue, I'd have been happy to provide it.  (See my comment to Andzrej about MEN ON.)

The OP also shows a gaping misunderstanding of how construction works, or they wouldn't be throwing around "lazy and unfair".  The construction of a puzzle with this kind of gimmick requires a great amount of work, more so than that of a regular puzzle.

And worst of all, that snarky "Please do better" at the end usually indicates that the solver is just not up to the task.  There are very few puzzles here that are so bad that they require major changes.  But there are a lot of solvers who just aren't up for the task.  Most of them, though, handle it gracefully and learn from their failure.  

To the occasional exception, I say, "Please do better."

@Ray No, but there's a big difference between someone saying they didn't like the puzzle vs saying it's 'awful', 'so bad.' This puzzle is not 'awful'. As you can see from other comments, many readers enjoyed it.
Clearly not my intent. Criticism when thoughtful is fair and welcome, their comment is just petty and childish. Big difference.

@ba 

My impression, from reading this column and comments for the past few years, is that there are points at which it is unavoidable to employ these (over)used words known as "crosswordese". (And yes, constraints such as grid size and layout, and themes, can greatly impact that!)

Then the construction focus becomes how uniquely can an answer be *clued* so that it is as fresh as possible. And for the solver, IMO there then is a line between "thank goodness, an oft-used answer is my lifeline!" (in a tricky puzzle) and your well-stated law of diminishing returns, or to me, a bit of a yawn... 

Among the regular commenters, there are a number of published constructors. I have read from them that it's usually a last resort to have to use crosswordese. So for me, I give a mental eyeroll and move on!  :)

@Ray 
It sure does seem that way most of the time, since those who express dislike for a particular puzzle usually get pilloried here.

@Andrzej 

Note that soccer has nothing of the sort of what I described in the second paragraph of the previous comment.  One goal at a time.  A 3-0 score with five minutes to play; it's over.

A 3-0 score with bases loaded in the bottom of the ninth, and it can be over in one swing with a home run, and a sudden reversal of fortune.  Four runs instead of zero. This is called a walk-off hit or homer because it ends the game. 

Heck, I've seen 7-run leads overturned in the ninth inning.  

Note:  One swing could end it with an opposite result, a triple play.  A rare play where three outs are made on the same play.  I've seen that happen, too.  Most commonly, a ground ball to the third baseman hit very close to the base.  He steps on third, throws quickly to second, and the ball is relayed to first.  All three bases are touched before the runner or batter gets there.  There's an average of five triple plays per year in Major League Baseball.

@NMarie
Should constructors avoid using the names of bad people or avoid allowing the names of good people to cross the bad? I don’t think they should labor under that restriction. We read, write, and talk about bad people all the time in real life, sometimes mentioning them in the same sentences with the good. Imposing such a burden would be especially onerous because we do not always agree on the good and the bad. For example, a strong case can be made against 43D (WILSON), although I won’t do so here, but his resting place made for an excellent clue. On the crossing issue, 32A was great in part because the subject’s first name is likely to be on the edge of memory for many of us, not too easy but not too obscure: “Oh right, I think it’s an M name, but what? Margaret, no, Marilyn, no …” Perfect, and all the more because the name MARIAN inspired me, as usual, to sing as much as I can remember of “Madam Librarian,” which amuses the dog. I gave zero thought to 21D except insofar as the A I’d filled in helped me think of it. To conclude, at long last, I would argue that the enjoyment of crossword puzzles is affected more by repetitiveness than anything else, which often can’t be helped, but it would be worse if we demanded that entries be policed for proper names or chance crossings with unpleasant associations for some. I’d rather leave our constructors and editors a wider field of operation even if it means I sometimes say to myself, “That guy was a real rat!”

@G 

Half-and-half is actually a bit lighter than single cream. Single cream is about 18% fat, so closer to light cream; whereas half-and-half is diluted down around 12%.

@G 
Single cream has about 18% fat. It can't be whipped up. It's not the same as half and half.

Whipping cream is about 40%  fat and can be poured or whipped up.

Double cream is 48% - 60% fat, can be poured or whipped up.

Sometimes gelatine or similar is used to 'thicken up' whipping cream.

Soured cream is single cream with a culture added to give a tart, sour taste.

Crème fraîche is double cream similarly altered. 

Clotted cream (from Devon, Cornwall and south of England)) has average of 64% fat, is used on scones for a "cream tea" and is produced slightly differently and is almost solid.

Buttermilk is rarely used.
